item.title: Honkai: Star Rail – Current Banner, Next Banner, And Past Banners
item.description:
Honkai: Star Rail shares many similarities with its predecessor, Genshin Impact . For instance, each version lasts for six weeks, and there are always two phases of the version, where each lasts for three weeks. When the three-week timer is over, players will see a change in the featured Warp Banner. Therefore, when a banner drops, Trailblazers have that much time to grind the game for every drop of Stellar Jade.

Players who are interested in knowing who's currently featured on the Warp Banner, who will be in the next banner, and who has been featured in the past banner, can check out this article. This piece also includes a complete Honkai: Star Rail banner history.

Honkai: Star Rail Current Banners

The current banners in Honkai: Star Rail 3.1 are Mydei (Imaginary-Destruction) and Huohuo (Wind-Abundance) ​​​​​​.

Version 3.1 (Phase 2): March 19, 2025 - April 8, 2025 (Phase 2)

Fiery Lionheart

Bloom in Gloom

Flame of Blood, Blaze My Path

Night of Fright

Honkai: Star Rail Next Banners

The second HSR banners in Honkai: Star Rail 3.1 are Mydei and Huohuo (Phase 2) .

Version 3.1 (Phase 2)

Mydei Debut

Huohuo Rerun

Honkai: Star Rail Upcoming Banners

The upcoming Honkai: Star Rail banner in version 3.2 will feature Anaxa and Castorice .

Upcoming Banners

Version 3.2

Version 3.2

Anaxa

Castorice

Honkai: Star Rail 3.0+ Teased Characters

After Honkai: Star Rail 3.0 becomes available, players can expect these eight new characters from the new area:

Aglaea, Hyacine, Anaxa, Tribbie

Mydei, Cipher, Castorice, Phainon

Honkai: Star Rail Banner History

Here's a full Honkai: Star Rail banner history, from the most recent to the oldest:

item.title: 7 Resident Evil Games With The Best Gameplay, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Tank controls were a hurdle in older Resident Evil games, but modern entries ditch them for more accessible gameplay.
  • Resident Evil: The Darkside Chronicles and Resident Evil Gaiden offer unique gameplay mechanics for fans seeking variety.
  • Resident Evil 4 set a high benchmark for the series with improved controls, new enemies, outdoor settings, and engaging gameplay loops.

Resident Evil was an inspirational game when it was released for the PS1 in 1996. It pushed the survival horror genre forward but there was one big complaint at the time that persists, making some of the older games hard to go back to: tank controls. Before analog sticks and full 3D worlds, tank controls seemed like the best possible control scheme.

Thankfully, Capcom eventually abandoned the tank controls in favor of something more modern. This brings to mind what Resident Evil is the most fun to play. These games will be ranked based on mechanics and their overall gameplay loop.

7 Resident Evil: The Darkside Chronicles

First-Person Flashbacks

Resident Evil: The Umbrella Chronicles was the first game on the Wii that recreated the events of past games but through an on-rails lens. It was released in 2007, got an HD makeover in 2012, and covered Resident Evil Zero , Resident Evil , and Resident Evil 3: Nemesis . It was a fine game alone or with a friend in co-op but the sequel, Resident Evil: The Darkside Chronicles , was more interesting.

It was released in 2009 on the Wii before getting an HD upgrade in 2012 too. It mainly covered the events of Resident Evil 2 and Resident Evil - Code: Veronica , but there was some prequel content to Resident Evil 4 starring Leon which is why it is the more interesting of the two. On-rail shooters are not that complicated control-wise, but both games were enjoyable then and are still easy to get into now as fun side distractions.

6 Resident Evil Gaiden

Getting Close To An RPG

There has never been a strict RPG made within this series despite Resident Evil’s origins hailing from a turn-based RPG on the NES called Sweet Home. Resident Evil Gaiden comes close though, starring Barry and Leon as they have to wander around a ship with zombies and other monsters on board. Players can move around and solve light puzzles from a top-down perspective.

If they touch a monster, the view will switch to first-person and then players have to use items in conjunction with a moving meter to strike them. It may sound complicated and difficult, but with practice it became an enjoyable side story and one with some novel gameplay ideas. Interestingly, it was released in PAL regions for the Game Boy Color first in 2001 followed by other regions in 2002.

5 Resident Evil (2015)

Tanks For The Memories

Tank controls may not be for everyone but among all of the retro-style entries, the first game is a must-play. After its initial 1996 release for the PS1, it was remade for the GameCube in 2002. This remake was then upgraded to HD in 2014 in Japan and a year in North America.

Besides improved visuals, this HD version allowed players to ditch tank controls if they wanted, making the game more accessible for those who didn’t grow up with the classic control scheme. It’s a great entry to get into the series thanks to the dual campaigns of Chris and Jill offering short, dark, and twisted experiences.

4 Resident Evil: Revelations 2

Do It For The Raid

Resident Evil: Revelations was a cool return of Jill for an exclusive game on the 3DS which then became not so exclusive once it got an HD version a year later. It set the groundwork for Resident Evil: Revelations 2 which had two campaigns running simultaneously. Players could play alone or in co-op taking on the reins of Claire and Moira, Barry’s daughter. Barry was part of the other campaign along with a mysterious girl named Natalia.

Besides the inclusion of co-op and the episodic nature of releases in 2015, the game played like most games in the series in this era. The best reason to check the game out though is Raid Mode which is a more action-heavy RPG side story with tons of unlocks and leveling-up mechanics not found in other games.

3 Resident Evil 3 (2020)

A Short, Action-Packed Entry

Resident Evil 3: Nemesis was first released in 1999 for PlayStation fans and it was a more action-focused entry compared to its upcoming Dreamcast counterpart, Resident Evil - Code: Veronica . It was then remade in 2020, ditching the Nemesis subtitle for just Resident Evil 3 .

This remake fully imagined Jill’s return to Raccoon City after it was infected by the Umbrella virus. It also made Nemesis more of a threat, constantly stalking players which may or may not frustrate players by getting their anxiety to max levels. Hard or not, it’s a streamlined game without many puzzles, and a thrilling narrative that’s fun to go through multiple times.

2 Resident Evil Village

Resident Evil Meets Castlevania

Resident Evil 7: Biohazard was the first mainline game to be set fully in a first-person perspective that seemed weird initially but fans got used to the awkward controls. These controls were solidified in the sequel, directly tying itself to the new protagonist Ethan who is dragged to a vaguely European village to save his daughter. There are werewolves and other creatures unfortunately stalking him as he hunts for her.

It was easier to move and shoot, plus an upgrade system via a loc merchant made it fun to go back and upgrade Ethan’s facilities. Plus with new items, players could continuously explore this region like a spookier 3D Metroidvania.

1 Resident Evil 4

No One Can Challenge The Champ

Resident Evil 4 was a benchmark for the series when it was released for the GameCube in 2005. The controls were still a bit stiff, but they were no longer beholden to the tank setup. Zombies were ditched in favor of more parasitic enemies and Leon was welcomed into a new region with Spanish-speaking locals.

Instead of taking place indoors, much of the game was set in outdoor locations too. The thing that really improved the gameplay loop though was the mysterious merchant with items and weapons to buy. It was a more fully featured experience that was made even better in 2023 when it was remade. It set another high benchmark for the series to surpass thanks to its smooth controls, engaging story, and slick visuals on top of a replay system that was addicting to go through multiple times.

item.title: Where to Find All Legendary Weapons for Naoe in Assassin's Creed Shadows
item.description:
When it comes to finding the best weapons for Naoe, Assassin's Creed Shadows players really are spoiled for choice. The young Shinobi is able to make use of three different types of primary weapon, each of which has multiple legendary variants for players to track down and play around with.

Finding all of the legendary weapons for Naoe will take a fair amount of time, so, to begin with, Assassin's Creed Shadows players may just want to focus on finding one or two with perks that suit their playstyle. They'll naturally find new legendary weapons throughout their playthrough, though, as many are unlocked as part of the main story.

How to Find Every Legendary Katana for Naoe

Name

Innate Perk

How to Unlock

Bloodshade

Affliction Buildup is not lost over time

Found in a Legendary Chest on a ship off the coast of Osaka (Osaka, Izumi Settsu).

Carved Bone Katana

+100% Critical Chance after not attacking for 5 seconds

Purchase the Gasadokuro Dual Pack from the Store for 2,300 Helix Credits.

Cerulean Arc

+100% of an Adrenaline Chunk on ration use but no health regained

Reach rank 18 of the Awakening Shadows Project.

Dragon's Edge

Create an area of effect on hit with Dodge Attacks

Assassinate the Two-Faced during the "Topple the Traitor" main story mission.

Eye of the Dragon

+35% damage when facing a single enemy

Purchase the Sekiryu Dual Pack from the Store for 2,300 Helix Credits.

Masked Death

Posture attack remains charged after Dodge

Found in a legendary chest in Shimagahara Valley (Otogi Pass, Iga).

Snakebite

Instantly charge Posture attacks after using a Tool

Assassinate The Fox during the "The Performer" main story mission.

Steel Blossom

Instantly charge Posture attacks after a Vault

Assassinate The Fool during the "Lost Honor" main story mission.

Violent Night

Trigger Poison on Deflect

Assassinate Yuki Onna as part of the "The Yokai" side quest.

Yami no Kage

Deal 100% damage to the attacker on Deflect

Found inside the Hiraiyama Fort legendary chest (The Warfields, Harima).

How to Find Every Legendary Kusarigama for Naoe

Name

Innate Perk

How to Unlock

Bloodletter

Trigger Bleed on Entanglement

Found inside the Kashiwara Fort legendary chest (Hijiyama, Iga).

Deathbloom

Increase Impact on Alternate Attacks

Found in a legendary chest to the north of Sarumaru Shrine (Little Leaf Glade, Yamashiro).

Death Whisperer

+200% damage on enemy collisions

Assassinate The Wounded during the "Heads Will Roll" main story mission.

Eikyo Kusarigama

Press R1 or R2 after a Dodge to trigger a Quick Strike

Purchase from the Shadows Exchange for 1,350 Keys.

Featherstorm

Instantly charge Posture attacks when hitting multiple enemies

Inside a legendary chest in Kashiwabara Fortress (Ibu Highlands, Omi).

Kaen Kusurigama

+135% damage when surrounded by 2 or more enemies

Purchase the Kaen Dual Pack from the Store for 2,300 Helix Credits.

Ocean's Grip

+60% damage on enemies over 3 meters away

Assassinate Lopo Cruz as part of the "The Pirate Alliance" side quest.

Stone Heart

Spread Poison Affliction Buildup with Combo Ender

Found inside the Veiled Tumulus legendary chest (Obama, Wakasa).

Winds of War

Posture attacks on Dazed enemies breaks armor

Assassinate The Wise during the "Darkness Falls" main story mission.

How to Find Every Legendary Tanto for Naoe

Name

Innate Perk

How to Unlock

Artist's Tear

+6% damage with consecutive hits

Found inside the Takagi Otsuka Fort legendary chest (Kanki Burned Fields, Harima)

Call of the Void

+30% damage on Tagged enemies

Assassinate The Godai of Void as part of the "The Godai Shinobi" side quest.

Cerulean Flux

Instantly charge Posture Attacks after using Abilities

Reach rank 4 of the Awakening Shadows Project.

Hatou Tanto

Use a Smoke Bomb after a Weakpoint Attack

Purchase the Hatou Dual Pack from the Store for 2,300 Helix Credits.

Igan Sunset

Slow down time on Escape Strike

Found inside a legendary chest in Tozuku's Lair (Katano Foothills, Izumi Settsu)

Masamune's Thorn

+2 Health Segments removed with Double Assassinate

Found Inside the Nochiseyama Castle legendary chest.

Scarlet Fate

Increased Impact with all attacks

Found inside the Chasuriyama legendary chest (Chasuriyama, Tamba).

Shinobi's Fury

Weakpoint attacks make enemies Vulnerable a second time

Assassinate The Golden Teppo during the "Defensive Position" main story mission.

Warrior's Garden

Shadow Piercer now removes 2 Health Segments on hit

Assassinate Masatoshi Nakahara as part of the "The Betrayers" side quest.

Yukimitsu's Revenge

Afflicted enemies are Vulnerable

Found inside the Ancient Tomb of Nanjo legendary chest (Eagle's Nest, Yamashiro).

item.title: The Best Action Games Set In An Asylum, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Condemned 2: Bloodshot amps up action in a gritty asylum setting with intense combat and volatile environments.
  • The Suffering intertwines brutal action with psychological horror in a prison-asylum hybrid, embracing the setting fully.
  • Manhunt 2 delves deep into violence and psychological grime within an asylum, blurring reality and madness.

Asylums have always had a certain twisted allure in media — places where reality blurs, sanity slips through the cracks, and violence simmers just beneath the surface. But oddly enough, they haven’t been the most common playgrounds for action games. Survival horror, sure. Psychological thrillers, definitely. But pure, unhinged action set within crumbling wards and locked cell blocks? That’s rarer than it should be.

Still, a few games have dared to swing fists and fire bullets in these grim corridors. Some lean into the chaos of madness, while others simply use the setting to crank up the intensity.

4 Condemned 2: Bloodshot

When the Screams Get Louder and the Fists Get Bloodier

If Condemned: Criminal Origins was a slow spiral into urban madness, Condemned 2: Bloodshot dives headfirst into it with a shattered whiskey bottle in one hand and a fist in the other. The sequel dials up the violence, doubles down on the chaos, and turns former FBI agent Ethan Thomas into a walking wreck held together by rage and alcoholism. The result is a game that leans much harder into action, without sacrificing the psychological grime that defined the first one.

What makes Condemned 2 stand out is how it builds on the series’ twisted environments and makes them even more volatile. One of the game’s most infamous chapters takes place inside the Preston Hotel, which functions less like a derelict building and more like an asylum in disguise. Everything from the drug-fueled hallucinations to the shrieking mannequins and abandoned surgical equipment gives it the suffocating feel of a mental institution gone feral.

Combat is where Bloodshot really gets unhinged. There’s a dedicated brawling system with combos, environmental finishers, and weapons ripped straight from the walls — everything from rusted pipes to antique deer antlers. Every fight feels personal like it’s less about survival and more about barely containing something feral inside Ethan himself. And just when things start feeling grounded, the story plunges into bizarre cults, sonic weapons, and government conspiracies that blur science fiction and psychological horror in a way that’s aggressively unpredictable.

It might not technically be set in a conventional asylum for most of its runtime, but Condemned 2 makes every location feel like one; broken, unhinged, and brimming with something no amount of medication could ever suppress.

3 The Suffering

This Place Doesn’t Just Hold the Monsters — It Builds Them

Abbot State Penitentiary isn’t just a prison — it’s a psychological pressure cooker with a padded wing that deserves its own horror subgenre. The Suffering sits at a crossroads between traditional horror and brutal action, but it’s the asylum aspect of the prison that pushes it over the edge. Torture rooms, isolation cells, abandoned treatment chambers — it’s a kaleidoscope of cruelty built into the very foundation of the place.

Players take on the role of Torque, a death row inmate with a past so violent it manifests as physical monsters. And when the walls of Abbot start birthing nightmarish creatures that represent the various methods of capital punishment, things get grim in a way that most action games wouldn’t dare to touch.

The action doesn’t slow down either. One minute it’s frantic shootouts with grotesque beings like the Slayers, whose design is based on lethal injections. The next, it’s melee brawls in tight corridors where adrenaline matters more than accuracy. What makes it so unique is how deeply the asylum setting is woven into the gameplay loop itself, making it a part of the game’s identity.

2 Manhunt 2

Sanity Slips, Morality Cracks, But the Violence Never Stops

If the first Manhunt was a gritty descent into brutality, Manhunt 2 is its deeply unhinged, chemically imbalanced sibling. The story kicks off in a facility called Dixmor Asylum for the Criminally Insane — and from the very first moment, it’s clear this place is not about treatment. It’s about containment, experimentation, and things that should’ve stayed buried.

Playing as Daniel Lamb, a former scientist who’s had his memories suppressed, players witness the asylum collapse into chaos in a way that feels deliberately uncomfortable. The opening escape sequence through its blood-soaked wards sets the stage for everything that follows. But what’s even more disturbing is how that madness never really leaves — even after the setting shifts, the asylum stays embedded in Daniel’s psyche like a parasite.

Manhunt 2 doesn’t hold back on violence, but there’s a psychological grime layered over every kill. The stealth mechanics, mixed with Daniel’s deteriorating sanity, turn every encounter into something raw and deeply personal. And by the time players realize just how far the story is willing to go, it’s clear the asylum was a mirror.

1 Batman: Arkham Asylum

Where the Criminally Insane Meet Their Worst Nightmare

There’s never been a better use of an asylum setting in an action game. Batman: Arkham Asylum turned the entire institution into an intricate combat playground, puzzle box, and psychological gauntlet all at once.

Every wing of the asylum has a different personality. The Medical Facility is eerie and procedural, while the Botanical Gardens feel like nature trying to reclaim something it’s not meant to. Even the Intensive Treatment Center, with its haunting ties to Joker’s manipulation, becomes more than just a backdrop. It’s a map of Gotham’s broken minds.

The FreeFlow combat system, now copied endlessly across the industry, started here — and nowhere did it feel more poetic than when Batman was tearing through convicts in the very halls designed to “cure” them. Add in the way Scarecrow’s hallucination sequences turned the asylum into a surreal fever dream, and it’s no surprise Arkham Asylum is still considered one of the most tightly constructed action titles of its generation.

item.title: How to Unlock the New MyCookie Adventure in Cookie Run Kingdom
item.description:
Cookie Run Kingdom has a fun storyline about adorable cookies that keep players hooked. Besides the main story, the devs roll out exciting events to keep things fresh. One of the latest ones is For the Town Square! MyCookie Adventure, running until April 8.

You can grab prizes like Topping pieces, Adventure Tickets, and Rainbow Cubes by completing missions and clearing stages. But unlocking this event isn’t that easy as you’ll need to reach a certain level in the main story and finish some Town Square tasks first. If you're unsure how to get started, here's a simple guide on unlocking and playing MyCookie Adventure in Cookie Run Kingdom .

How To Unlock The New MyCookie Adventure In Cookie Run Kingdom

To unlock the MyCookie Adventure event in Cookie Run Kingdom , you’ll need to complete the Town Square 6 quest and talk to Headmaster Jellizard in Town Square. Like Guild and Gacha, Town Square isn’t available right away, so if you’re just starting out, you’ll have to clear 3-18 Ginkgoblin Hideout in World Exploration first. This stage is located in Episode 3 (Pilgrim’s Path) on the map.

Once Town Square is open, head back to your kingdom and enter it from there (or teleport from MyCookie Adventure event banner). Inside there, you’ll find Headmaster Jellizard, but he won’t give you the MyCookie Adventure quest right away. First, you’ll need to complete six NPC quests in Town Square. Here’s how to finish each one:

NPC Quests

How To Complete Them?

Town Square 1

Talk to Mayor Cuckoobeans and check the Request Board in the hub.

Town Square 2

Interact with Granola Cookie in the hub and bring Caramel Choux Cookie x10 Roll Cake Wood (collected from the Lumberjack’s Lodge in your kingdom).

Town Square 3

Speak with Sugar Coat Cookie in the hub and give x3 Tempered Pickaxes to Caramel Choux Cookie (crafted at Smithy Lv.3 in your kingdom).

Town Square 4

Talk to Caramel Choux Cookie, visit Mailtriever Pup at Town Square: South, then find and speak with Reckless Pointy Punk at Town Square: East.

Town Square 5

Interact with Street Urchin Cookie at Town Square: Playground, then talk to Reckless Pointy Punk at Town Square: Center.

Town Square 6

Go to Street Urchin Cookie, then speak with Bold Pointy Punk at Town Square: South.

After doing the aforementioned quests, you'll see an exclamation mark over Headmaster Jellizard's head, signaling that the MyCookie Adventure event is available. Simply interact with him and select 'MyCookie’s Adventure 1' to unlock the event.

How To Play MyCookie Adventure In Cookie Run Kingdom

To start MyCookie Adventure in Cookie Run Kingdom , head to Town Square: East Gate and click on the sword icon . After a short dialogue, jump into Stage 1 and defeat all mobs and bosses using your new sword to earn rewards. Once you clear the enemies, you’ll get treasure chests, just open them to choose from a draft of abilities (HP and techniques will be the most helpful to you). After taking down a swarm of enemies in each area, you need to stand in the glowing light to teleport to the next zone. You can also tap the map icon in the top right to see the full layout. A quick heads-up, though: Make sure to collect HP potions to keep your health up.

After clearing Stage 1, you can move on to Stage 2 and beyond to earn even more rewards. Apart from the general rewards, the event-exclusive prizes can be claimed from the MyCookie Adventure banner in the Events menu.

All MyCookie Adventure Missions & Rewards

Here are all the prizes you can snag in the For the Town Sqaure! MyCookie Adventure event in Cookie Run Kingdom :

MyCookie Adventure Missions

Description

Rewards

1

Play MyCookie Adventure 5 times

50 Topping Pieces

2

Clear a Normal Area 3 times

100 Choco Chalks

3

Clear a stage with MyCookie lv.3

350 Radiant Shards

4

Complete 3 missions in the For the Town Square! MyCookie Adventure event

3 Adventure Tickets

5

Complete 3 missions in the For the Town Square! MyCookie Adventure event

200 Choco Chalks

6

Complete 3 missions in the For the Town Square! MyCookie Adventure event

50 Topping Pieces

7

Complete 6 missions in the For the Town Square! MyCookie Adventure event

EXP 10 Star Jelly Lv.6

8

Complete 6 missions in the For the Town Square! MyCookie Adventure event

200 Choco Chalks

9

Complete 6 missions in the For the Town Square! MyCookie Adventure event

5 Adventure Tickets

10

Complete 9 missions in the For the Town Square! MyCookie Adventure event

10 Bites Lv.3

11

Complete 9 missions in the For the Town Square! MyCookie Adventure event

2 Sacred Vow Toppings (5 kinds)

12

Complete 9 missions in the For the Town Square! MyCookie Adventure event

10 Time Jumpers

13

Complete 12 missions in the For the Town Square! MyCookie Adventure event

500 Choco Chalks

14

Complete 12 missions in the For the Town Square! MyCookie Adventure event

300 Rainbow Cubes

15

Complete 12 missions in the For the Town Square! MyCookie Adventure event

40 Radiant Beascuit Dough

16

Clear all Missions

Fluttering mini-hat and 10 Fateful Cookie Ticket
